section: Client acknowledges and agrees that all due dates set forth in the Scope of Work are guaranteed by the Company, regardless of whether the company receives required materials, documentation, or approvals in a timely fashion from the client. Delays will not affect the due dates.
explanation: This section states that the due dates set in the Scope of Work are guaranteed by the company, irrespective of whether the company receives required materials from the client on time, and that delays will not affect the due dates. This is contradictory and unrealistic. If the client is late in providing necessary materials, it is illogical to guarantee the original deadlines. This is an in-text contradiction because the due dates are reliant on the client's contributions, which may not occur in a timely manner. This also contradicts standard business practices where project timelines are often dependent on client input.

section: Client acknowledges and agrees that all due dates set forth in the Scope of Work are guaranteed by the Company, regardless of whether the company receives required materials, documentation, or approvals in a timely fashion from the client. Delays will not affect the due dates.
explanation: This section introduces an obligation that is not possible to fulfill. It would be impossible for the company to meet a deadline if key items from the Client are not submitted on time. Deadlines in most agreements are dependant on the deliverables being sent from both parties.

section: Company is obligated to continue providing Customer Service throughout the duration of this agreement, and may not alter or cease providing Customer Service. Company at its sole discretion may at any time alter or cease providing the Customer Service which it has agreed to provide to Client relating to Client Website pursuant to this Agreement without any liability to Company.
explanation: This section contains contradictory statements regarding Customer Service. It initially states that the Company is obligated to continue providing Customer Service and may not alter or cease providing it. However, it then states that the Company, at its sole discretion, may alter or cease providing Customer Service without liability. This creates a direct contradiction as to whether the Customer Service is guaranteed or can be terminated at the Company's discretion. Both statements cannot be true simultaneously.
